awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Spatiotemporal Regulation of the Ethylene Signaling Network and Rapid Adaptive Responses in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to better understand how the gaseous plant hormone ethylene, commonly produced when plants are under stress, acts to regulate adaptation to various environmental inputs such as drought, chilling, salinity, flooding and nutrient deficiency. All of these stresses commonly affect the growth and reproduction of plants, ultimately threatening global food security. Plants undergo adaptive responses to these stresses by modifying physiological processes in which plant hormones such as ethylene play a pivotal role. This project will not only uncover the role of ethylene in plant adaptive response, potentially contributing to improving sustainable agriculture and food security, it will also provide research training for one postdoctoral scientist and two graduate students. The project leaders will also mentor undergraduate students through summer internship opportunities as well as other undergraduate research activities. In addition, the project will provide outreach activities to the general public, focusing on local high school students by allowing them to experience personal laboratory exercises and research presentations.

Rapid adaptation of plants to their surroundings is a critical trait for the survival of the plant and is regulated by how fast plants alter their growth patterns by modulating cellular dynamics. However, little is known about the fundamental aspects of adaptive responses such as response kinetics and the correlation of these kinetics with cellular events. The goal of this research is to fill this knowledge gap by utilizing ethylene-regulated dark-grown seedlings as a model system. The plant hormone ethylene plays a key role in plant adaptation, in addition to its well-known function in plant growth and development. Furthermore, dark-grown seedlings provide an excellent model system to study plant adaptation, as ethylene-induced changes are easy to trigger and to assay and the signaling pathway has been well characterized. Moreover, several studies indicate that the reversible growth kinetics of dark-grown seedlings in response to ethylene is closely regulated by the spatiotemporal regulation of ethylene signaling molecules. This provides a unique opportunity to study the correlation between adaptive response kinetics with the altered cellular dynamics directing this change. In order to accomplish these research goals, the investigators will determine the movement kinetics of the central ethylene signaling molecules in response to ethylene using cell biology approaches and its relation to the growth kinetics of dark-grown seedlings using high-resolution, time-lapse imaging analysis. In addition, they will test the hypothesis that a RAF-like protein kinase called Constitutive Triple Response 1 (CTR1), a negative regulator of ethylene signaling, plays a key role in a rapid resetting of the ethylene response, leading to faster growth recovery of dark-grown seedlings after ethylene treatment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The studies supported by this award focused on understanding the spatiotemporal regulation of plant hormone ethylene signaling. The ethylene signaling pathway controls many important agricultural traits, including fruit ripening, senescence, root growth, nodulation, and responses to various stresses. By gaining a better understanding of how ethylene signaling is regulated, we can optimize and develop new crop genotypes with improved performance and stress tolerance.

Ethylene signaling influences plant growth and stress responses primarily through transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulation. This regulation is closely tied to the spatiotemporal control of key signaling components. Recent research has shown that the activation of ethylene signaling relies on the movement of a critical component from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to the nucleus and processing bodies, highlighting the significance of these regulatory mechanisms. To further our understanding of the spatiotemporal regulation of ethylene signaling, we employed interdisciplinary approaches combining genetics, cell biology, biochemistry, and proteomics to dissect the subcellular localization of Constitutive Triple Response 1 (CTR1), a key negative regulator of ethylene responses, in response to ethylene. Initial studies identified that ER-localized CTR1 translocates into the nucleus in response to ethylene. Through this award, we discovered the core mechanism underlying this subcellular translocation of CTR1 and its biological function. We found that upon perception of ethylene at the ER, CTR1 moves to the nucleus, a process that requires the displacement of the N-terminus, which is normally needed to tether CTR1 to the ER, and occurs independently of its kinase activity. Time-lapse ethylene response growth kinetics analysis and molecular biochemical analysis showed that nuclear-localized CTR1 enhances ethylene responses by stabilizing Ethylene-Insensitive 3 (EIN3), the core ethylene transcription factor, thus shifting from a negative regulator to a positive regulator of ethylene responses. Corroborating this, Arabidopsis plants with increased amounts of nuclear CTR1 exhibit significant tolerance to drought and salinity stress. These results reveal a novel regulatory mechanism by which plants enhance their responses to environmental stress by modulating the spatiotemporal patterns of key ethylene signaling components. In line with the subcellular shuttling of CTR1, we identified several novel CTR1-interacting proteins that localize to various cellular organelles, including the nucleus, mitochondria, peroxisomes, plasma membrane, and Golgi. This suggests that ethylene signaling interacts with various cellular processes occurring at different subcellular locations, and CTR1 may play a central role in these processes. Overall, our results provide new insights into the regulation of ethylene signaling, which is crucial for plant stress responses. These findings could pave the way for crop development strategies focused on improving stress tolerance. By targeting the subcellular localization of key regulators such as CTR1, we may be able to develop crops with enhanced resistance to drought and salinity, addressing critical agricultural challenges posed by climate change.

This study also strengthened research and educational infrastructure by providing hands-on training to a diverse group of individuals, including high school students, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. The training covered a broad range of techniques in molecular biology, genetics, cell biology, and proteomics. Students and postdocs were also encouraged to attend various conferences to present their research findings, gaining opportunities for professional development and helping them build connections within the scientific community. We further engaged with the community through outreach programs such as PC-MASI, Purdue Spring Fest, and the NSF REU program, aimed at educating the public and fostering future scientists.
